title: Make your projects durable - cache aggresively
tweetText: If you're building a project that aggregates, I highly suggest making it as *durable* as possible. What this means is building an aggressive caching layer in your app. eg. do you grab user pfps? Cache those! Harden your app so it works, even in airplane mode. Nowadays, space is cheap! #buildinpublic

Obviously, there's a time & place for such industrial-grade tools. But your personal site is likely not one of them.

title: How will Bluesky monetize?
tweetText:
Aggregation platforms like FB/IG/X make their money by lifting the toll "one layer up". ie. inserting ads into feeds. Essentially, this is the "price" they charge users in return for hosting/aggregating/distributing UGC.

The bsky model (for now) gives away those services for free. I've recently been thinking a lot ab what are other ways that bsky could monetize? "ü§î"

title: Jay Graber: 'Social is stagnating... users are locked in; developers locked out'

title: Human-World Fit (HWF)
tweetText: We talk a lot ab "Product-Market-Fit". But what I think is equally important is "Human-World-Fit". Basically, existing a certain way in the world that makes you happy. Just like PMF, HWF requires enduring many failures. Keep trying new behaviors & values until you find your fit.

title: Lack of pain/pressure
tweetText:
Lack of pain/pressure.

As I've aged, I've found that I've generally mellowed. The drive & ambition of my younger years have greatly diminished & I've largely come to peace w/ who I am & am mostly content/happy w/ life.

Idk if this is true, but I feel if I were less content & more uncertain of myself & what I wanted from life, then I'd be more agentic.

In other words, I think when you're at 50% happiness, it's relatively easy to summon the discipline & drive to get to 90% happiness. But once you're at 90% (for me at least), summoning the agency to go the last 10% just hasn't been there.

title: Nobody Cares | Grant Slatton
tweetText:
Hi @GrantSlatton - I just read your great rant at https://grantslatton.com/nobody-cares & wanted to TY for sharing. If you ever start your utopian society, pls lmk; I'd love to apply to join. As someone who once cared very deeply but has since been whittled down, your post deeply resonated. One other note, btw: your observations ab Japan are spot-on; it's definitely a cultural thing and Japan has only been able to maintain that culture bc they're so culturally homogenous.

In a land like the US where we have ppl from all over, it becomes a much more difficult project. It's like you noted towards the end: I think all people hate "being the sucker". Like, it's very difficult to continue going above & beyond when you see everyone around you not upholding the same standard. So then, over time, you too will then stop installing dog bag dispensers & so forth.

Anyway, TY for fighting the good fight. "ü´°"

title: Return to Bluesky
tweetText:
I started posting & replying on bsky yesterday (after an 8mo hiatus) & wow: that site is totally the opposite of my X exp. 1) Though I'm only following 7ppl, my feed is definitely much more liberal & 2) Ppl engage way more! Some are ad hominem (but I just insta-block them) but others are thoughtful ppl who take the time to reply w/ useful info. This is in stark contrast to X where I basically get no replies ever. (But X is still enormously useful as a public recording platform.)

Anyway, I'll keep experimenting with bsky. One really cool thing ab that platform is that API integration is *super-easy*. ie. It's very simple to programmatically post (w/ images) to the platform. I'm going to play around w/ this more. But basically, I think there's value in being able to "write once & post everywhere". X & Bsky are essentially increasingly the "messaging busses" of humanity.

Props to what @aworkinglibrary wrote: I really encourage folks to try distributing snippets of their writing on the different major social platforms. There is definitely something fertile & promising to be explored w/ this means of distribution.

title: AI trains only on exteriority + Every man's secret heart
tweetText:
So I've thought ab this before. And while I'm willing to try it out (pls do share the 100 open-ended Qs, Ben!), I am skeptical bc I believe that for all ppl, even prolific writers w/ the fecundity of DFW across all domains & formats (magazine spreads, novels, personal letters) that so much of what makes us, us, is still captured in unstructured memories & experiences that are only in our latent consciousness.

Notably, this is completely different than simply "jogging" a memory. The reason jogging a memory works is bc you have the fundamental, original memory to return to. And AI will not have that; AI only has whatever you trained it on. So whatever "resurrection" you may conjure will always be a poor facsimile, unable to fully capture the fidelity of the original.

Now: if AI wearables/apps (Friend pendant, Rewind app, Meta Raybans, the cowboy hats in Westworld) catch on and the AIs start recording everything in your life experience from birth, then we're closer. But even then, the question now turns into a BF Skinner behaviorism question. Is the sum of a person everything you can simply observe via their exteriority? Or is there some interiority ‚Äîsome part of the human soul‚Äî that is always hidden, never outwardly observable?

title: Power outage bc of Hurricane Helene
tweetText:
Last night, like thousands of others in Ohio, I'd lost power bc of Hurricane Helene. (I honestly hadn't even known it was possible for the Midwest to get hurricanes, seriously.) I was one of the lucky ones so the outage was only ~5:45p to ab midnight. It was still a weird evening though. I was literally typing one of my final Slack messages for work for the week when the grid went. (I just finished typing it on my phone & sending it; the draft had synced flawlessly! TY, Salesforce! Keeping work uninterrupted even as civilization crumbled! "üí™") And luckily, there were still a few hours of daylight left. We got dinner at a nearby sushi place (that'd been unaffected, somehow) & then bought some candles & returned home.

I really enjoyed the downtime, personally. I even got some writing done on my phone which still had 4G. Obviously, I don't want rolling blackouts every week. But the whole ~6 hour experience made me think that the Jewish with their Shabbat practice are onto something, as are the Amish & their disinclination/selective use of electricity. I haven't put all the pieces together yet, but last night when we all returned to basics, we regained something raw, fundamental, and human. (To be clear though, I'm glad the return was short enough so none of the food in our fridge spoiled.) Still, it was long enough to shake me from my weekly Friday evening routine stupor. Thank you, Universe!! "üôè""üåå"

title: a16z | Governing democracy on the internet
tweetText:
https://a16z.simplecast.com/episodes/governing-democracy-the-internet-and-boardrooms‚Ä¶

Good listen this week. Three big challenges according to @NoahRFeldman & @ahall_research for exercising democracy on a global platform:

1. Trolls who lack skin in the game (the "Boaty McBoatface" problem). Also: general lack of participation often selects for ppl w/ extreme preferences.

2. Who gets to decide the policy? eg. The definitions of X or Y or Z? Geographically, laws make sense bc ppl can't easily relocate for advantage (eg. for a school district for their kids). But with VPNs, if policies simply changed based on your IP, things will get hyper-balkanized quickly.

3. Who is the denominator? Voting is a means of self-determination & governance for a local population. eg. New Yorkers care ab congestion pricing bc that directly affects their QoL in Manhattan. Both drivers & non-drivers alike are affected.

But on a global platform, what is the "local population" that voting is meant to serve?

title: Amazon's 5-day RTO mandate
tweetText:
I love this Amazon 5d RTO take, especially highlighting all the reasons cities give such massive tax breaks for office HQs.

While I totally understand why ppl like WFH & avoiding 1-2 hour commutes, at the day's end I'm a collectivist on this. We all worked 5d a week at the office before. We can certainly do it again. Yes, individuals (especially parents of young children) may struggle more. And yes, I even grant some of you may be *less* productive at the office. But in my mind, all the benefits to the *surrounding office areas* are worth it. More money for small businesses like cafes and restaurants. More people doing stuff outside together after work bc they're already out. More foot traffic revitalizing our downtown urban cores or even the areas surrounding office parks. The list goes on and on.

Ultimately, I just don't want to live in a dystopian world where everyone's WFH and society is atomized. I want a society that is vibrant, connected, and alive! Not just with everyone stuck in their own individual bubbles at home all the time.

I'm "üíØ" with Jassy on this one.

title: Journey from v1-v3: SpaceX Raptor Rocket
tweetText:
I love this progression so much. It's essentially a tale of doing something for the first time. Running, coding, writing, etc.

When you first learn to run long distances, you have so much extra movement in your motion. Over time, it's about maximizing efficiency: to maximize output while minimizing effort (ie. minimizing wasted movement).

Same goes for coding. The first time you learn a new framework or write a new app, you write so much extra code. All superfluous & loc you eventually discard. But you can only get to the final product by writing (and deleting during refactors) all that extra code.

And then, finally: writing. All the plot lines that never went anywhere. All the characters that never developed. All the reams of exposition and background descriptions that have no purpose. In the last mile, you just carve all that away. Weeks and months of effort, gone, bc they no longer serve the greater story when you read everything together.

If there's a way to directly go from v0 to v3, I'm all ears. If there's an easier way to do it, please lmk.

Until then, just keep chugging on. You'll delete most of it later. But ime, there's simply just no other way to get there. "ü´°"

title: The crux of 'mind magic'
tweetText:
"üíØ"this. Also: this is why meditation is so important. (Or at least some ritual where you quiet your mind & baseline on what you genuinely want, filtering all the noise from signal in your head.) Additionally: this is why forming the right habits are critical. The idea is to get to a place where you 24/7 leverage your own limited perception & human biases in your favor. So your narrow cone of perception then synchronizes between your "internal state" & "the external world".

When this happens, every "setback" in the external world will be exactly that in your mind: in air quotes. Your mind will interpret every setback as a lesson or opportunity. And every gift or door that opens will feel divinely ordained, feeding your confirmation bias that you're "on the right path".

Related: on X, I've noticed that people like to dunk on "copes" a lot. And I agree that a rationalization ab something suboptimal can certainly be the first step towards an unhealthy cope. But if that rationalization turns into the basis for action, then you've turned the tables. There's that old line about, "chips on the shoulder yield chips in the pocket." Turn a bad childhood upbringing into a struggle essay that gets you into a selective college. Or use that speeding ticket as a constant reminder that you should drive safer when your kids are in the backseat. Copes can become lemonade if you action on them. Make your copes serve you.

One final note: someone else in the comments mentioned something ab, "working hard". Working hard is not enough. This is the entire idea of "mind magic". You need to actually put a destination into the nav system first before you enable autopilot. Otherwise, you will go through life as an NPC.

title: More thoughts on 'Founder Mode'
tweetText:
More thoughts on "Founder Mode": to me, the core of the idea is retaining a founder's intensity & focus in the culture as the org scales. Founders set the tone of a company. Traditional b-school models of adding modularity & management layers dilutes a founder's spirit & intentionality. A company dies when it loses its spirit. "Founder Mode" is a way to keep that spirit alive by having the founder not just micromanaging but seeming to "be" everywhere all the time.

More specifically, a company doesn't die all at once. It dies gradually. As orgs scale, people stop pushing as hard as they once did. They have families and develop new priorities. Rigor slowly decreases. So forth.

To fight this organizational calcification requires tremendous intentionality. Founder Mode is a way of keeping one's hand on the rudder for as long as possible as the boat grows and grows, and keeps getting faster.

(Tactically, I've found ~90 min one-way to be optimal; so ~3 hrs round-trip.) Pick a spot somewhere new on the map to visit. Walk around downtown. Visit a small cafe or shop. Buy a small souvenir. title: The fragmentation of social media
tweetText:
What we're witnessing is a fracturing & fragmentation of social; everyone is now self-sorting onto their respective platforms that align w/ their values.

Bsky land is where feelings reign supreme above all else. eg. feelings are more important than accountability & responsibility. (This maps closely w/ how the physical world has also bifurcated.) There's a subset of ppl in the world who simply dislike negative feelings; they prefer to just not see it rather than to wrestle with certain ideas or feedback. (Brandon's AA example is really apt here; ppl largely attend AA to be affirmed, validated, & boosted. And that's fine! It's an important forum for an important function.)

Personally, I love getting replies in X though, even more than getting likes. Sure, a like is fine‚Äî a dopamine hit of validation. But far more interesting (to me at least) is when someone disagrees & takes the time to at least give a small explanation.

What remains to be seen is monetization-wise, will bsky, with its "feelings-first" approach be successful? Like with all things, the market will decide!

title: A Sinking Tide Lowers All Boats
tweetText:
A Sinking Tide Lowers All Boats

The idea that taxes on unrealized capital gains for ppl making over $100m won't affect many of us is wrong. Yes, only a tiny fraction would pay this tax. But in order to foot the tax bill every year, the ultra-wealthy would need to come up w/ the cash some way, right? And they'd likely sell stock? Thus, anyone who has a 401k, IRA, or any money invested in the market would also be adversely impacted.

Additionally, nowadays, more & more ppl are increasingly invested in the equity markets (thanks, Robinhood!) It used to be very gatekept (there were transaction fees on every trade!) but now with commission-free trading, anyone can participate in the spoils of a booming market.

I'm honestly confused by ppl who are advocating for this; taxing unrealized capital gains seems like the exact opposite of a "rising tide lifts all boats". Equity markets are one of the few ways for normal people (Main Streeters) to amass great wealth in the US. Why take away this avenue of success from everyone?

title: Mark Twain on trouble: 'It ain't what you don't know...'
tweetText:
To quote the legendary Mark Twain:

"It ain‚Äôt what you don‚Äôt know that gets you into trouble. It‚Äôs what you know for sure that just ain‚Äôt so."

For anyone not already playing NYT's Connections, I highly recommend it. What's great ab the game is that it forces a kind of plasticity of mind if you wish to be successful. Meaning: you'll get it into your head that certain words are connected in a specific way. And they are! But they're also connected to other words in other ways that you hadn't initially thought of. And so letting go of your earlier convictions to try new connections in the face of new data becomes critical to winning.

Everyone should play Connections. Fight thought calcification and sclerotic thinking!! "üß†""üí™"

title: Equality vs Equity + Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn
tweetText:
I really like this pic of "equality vs equity" (much more than the "baseball fence" pic) bc it takes into account the dimension of time. I am 100% against "equality of outcome". But I'm onboard w/ trying to make the starting line as near as same for all.

It makes sense to me that in a world where we're all different, that we'll all eventually end up in different places. Some work harder than others & are more ambitious so they'll get ahead. Some are more gifted so they'll have natural advantages in music & sports. Asking everyone to end in the same place is a recipe for disaster & is a tragic world.

IOW, I like the idea that everyone at least has a functioning bike at life's outset. But note this says nothing at all to how far they'll actually get in life. Some will go much farther than others, and that's okay. In fact, I'd wish it no other way.

title: The Broad and Narrow Way (1883)
tweetText:
The Broad and Narrow Way (1883)

I love this painting so much & it increasingly resonates as I get older. Its original context is from the bible. But I've personally interpreted the art more as the difference between leading a life w/ specific values versus one without.

Living a life with rigid values means you will lead a narrower life, one where you meet fewer people & partake in fewer life experiences. But it also means you lead, in a way, an easier life. Your decisions are easier because you have specific values that you can easily fall back on. You're not conflicted bc the way forward is always clear. (The canonical example I always think of are vegetarians: they'll never know what meat tastes like, but they'll always know what they want to eat.)

Living a life with more relaxed values means the opposite: yes, you'll experience more of what life has to offer. But the tradeoff for that flexibility is that you'll spin a lot of cycles trying to navigate difficult dilemmas and have to proportionately make tougher choices. You'll often be internally conflicted. And you'll often be more lost, bc you've chosen a life that requires more wandering.

To be clear, there is no right and wrong camp. And it obviously can change too, depending on your life stage. I personally know people in both camps who report and present as perfectly happy. It all just depends on your own specific disposition and most people live on a spectrum somewhere between the two poles.

Personally, for me: when I was younger, I was definitely more in the "rigid values" camp. "A is A". Right and wrong were always very clear to me. Then as I got older --specifically, after I got married-- I gave up on many of my values (the old adage about "you can be principled or you can be married") and wandered the desert for a while. But now I'm even older and have gotten some time to recalibrate to married life (it's essentially comparable to going from straightforward Euclidean geometry to not just Riemann geometry, but n-th dimensions, seriously), I'm beginning to anchor back to having more rigid values again.

title: Peter Thiel on the 'Dual Use' problem of nuclear
tweetText:
Since seeing this a week ago, I'd been puzzled. Lots of ppl on X have been accusing Germany of being "stupid". But I don't find that explanation sensible at all.

Rather, listening to the Rogan/Thiel interview, Thiel said something that makes much more sense to me.

Thiel calls it the "dual use" problem. Basically, in 1974, India successfully detonated a nuclear weapon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smiling_Buddha‚Ä¶) and it turns out, that'd only been possible bc of technology transfer from the US in order to give nuclear energy to India.

According to Thiel, once a country gets nuclear energy, it actually then becomes easy to weaponize an atomic bomb. The thinking is then: since nuclear technology is so dangerous, we need to contain it as much as possible. And that's why there have actively been efforts to limit nuclear as an energy resource and slow its adoption & spread.

Here's the original JRE clip: https://youtube.com/watch?v=klRb0_BAX9g&t=2970s‚Ä¶

title: Fireworks in Quebec City
tweetText:
Every Tue & Thu at 10p in Aug, the ppl of Quebec City get a free fireworks show! It's 20min long & bigger than many of the Jul 4 shows I've seen in the US. Happens over the St. Lawrence River.

Apparently, it's funded by the CAD government, mostly from lottery funds.

It's been fun visiting another country & seeing how they prioritize different societal values. By offering a free communal event like this biweekly in Aug, it incentives folks to get out, hang out in a public space, & then spend money in the local economy (restaurants, pubs, cafes) beforehand.

Ppl often talk a lot ab "building community". But to do that, you need social infrastructure to weave the communal fabric.

https://quebec-cite.com/en/what-to-do-quebec-city/events/grands-feux-loto-quebec‚Ä¶

title: Micro vs macro
tweetText:
IMHO, this is a wrong take. This is an example where what's good at the micro level is not applicable at the macro level. (Another example is debt. What works at a national level isn't advisable at a household level, for various reasons bc what you're optimizing for at each level is different.)

I agree that for roommates & marriages, sharing common core values is paramount. "‚úÖ"

But when it comes to society (& here, I'm thinking ab the US, specifically), the ability to agree to disagree is critical, while still working together on other things. We must be able to get along, at least in common spaces & at the workplace.

What religions ppl celebrate at home is their own business. But when they show up for their job at the office (or WFH when they hop on Zoom or deliver work), then it's mission-first for whatever is best for the company. (Personal values are subservient to company values at the workplace. If you don't like your company's values, don't work there.)

Same goes for public spaces. In public spaces, there must be a minimum code. The great thing ab America is that these codes differ *a lot* state-by-state.

If you are more liberal & like paying higher taxes, then move to SF & CA. If you're more conservative, move to a red state. And even within states, there are huge differences too. (eg. I live in Cincinnati & we have an area called Indian Hills where the wealthy residents have their own police force & gated park. But then there are other parts of Ohio that are definitely more collective & communal. In Mason, for example, there is a huge Indian enclave. (When I lived in NJ, it was like this too. Huge Indian enclaves!) And in CA, there are also entire areas where the signage is all in Chinese. No English in sight! In America!)

America is vibrant & strong bc we're able to harness the best from all cultures, religions, & backgrounds. The diversity is real, not just lip service, & we ought celebrate that. (Just look at the ethnicities of many of the American athletes competing at the Olympics right now.) We have 50 states. Move to the one that most shares your values. There's enough room for all of us here.

title: How travling has chnaged now I'm old
tweetText:
It's been a while since I've traveled. One obs: when I was younger, I enjoyed planning the trip probably as much as taking the trip. Using points to book hotels for a good deal, figuring out all the Byzantine rules ab car rentals, planning the itinerary.

Now I'm old, I hate the planning. I just want to enjoy the experience. I want to simply be in the place, seeing the things, soaking it all in.

When you're young, the world is still novel. You're learning everything w/ fresh eyes & still building corpus. You're also still not committed to a project yet.

Once I got old though, my mind is often elsewhere. A passage I'm trying to write. Or a new project I'm thinking ab starting.

title: Training for the Olympics is a lifestyle
tweetText:
Watching the Olympics this past week has reminded me to appreciate the difference between an activity & a lifestyle. For most of us, sports are just hobbies; passing activities we do in our free time, in an isolated context. But for professionals, their sports are lifestyles. Their sleeping patterns, diets, & every waking moment of their day center around their sport.

If you wish to be the very best in something, it means throwing balance out & going for the extreme. By definition, excellence is not achieved by normal & balanced ppl. Excellence is achieved by extremists obsessed w/ their craft & pursing being the absolute best. Training & competing at the expense of just ab all else.

Sometimes, I wonder: if you took that same fanaticism & discipline that professional athletes commit to their sports, but applied it to something else (coding, writing, drawing, etc), what results would that yield?

title: Life's biggest unlock: journal publicly
tweetText:
There's so much alpha in consistently setting aside an hour every day to sit down, reflect, & journal. Recently, I've been doing this every morning (I've set up a little workspace on my kitchen table) before my day begins.

Throughout the day, I'm inundated w/ content. Podcasts, articles, conversations. In the evenings, while eating, I may then watch a TV show or some of the Olympics on YT.

And all that's fine. But w/o setting time aside to synthesize all that content, it just all washes over me & passes right through my body. That old line ab "seeing & hearing everything, but retaining nothing".

This is a drum I'll beat forever, but the one biggest unlock, IMHO, for everyone is journaling publicly. (I happen to like X, but do it anywhere.) I used to see it as narcissistic & self-involved to microblog, but I've changed my views on that. It's a way to help others discover you by sharing stuff you're thinking ab or working through each & every day. And it also helps mark time, which feels like it's passing faster & faster every year.

PS. Harry birthday, Harry!! "üéÇ"

title: 'Shit's pretty easy if you just... let it suck'
tweetText:
"Embrace the suck"

X is great bc you'll read a tweet, bookmark/like it; but then not suddenly think ab it until a few weeks later. Like this one:

"One guy said something I'll never forget, "shit's pretty easy if you just... let it suck, y'know what I mean?"

Sometimes things are simply awful & it's necessary to just power through them. They can't be optimized; they simply need to be endured.

In this category:
1. One-off events. Just suffer through them to get the thing done. If it happens frequently, then sure-- optimize. Else, premature optimization is the root of all ails, etc.

2. Subroutines which are "part and parcel" to the overall process. So for example: exercising. Anytime when exercising, there's always the first ten minutes before you've broken a sweat. I hate these first ten minutes. (Maybe everyone does?) But once you get into the groove, then it's fine. But until then, those first 10 minutes stink.

Also: any kind of creative work. (IME at least.) Idk if there's a better way to "do creative stuff" (any act that requires active generation of novel content) but for me there's always an infertile stretch of dead space before cylinders start correctly firing.

title: Fiction Writing as a Bottom-Up Process
tweetText: Idk how other ppl write fiction. But what I've learned ab (trying) to write fiction is that I cannot force it. I may feel like I have some brilliant top-down idea of how I wish for the story to go. But whenever I try to force it, things just don't work. Instead, for me it's become a bottom-up process where I create the "clay" on my first pass. And then I use top-down processes later in my second & subsequent passes to mold that clay & stich together what works. Again, maybe there's a better way to do it. But I haven't found it.

title: Playing Life On Hard Mode (a life without children)
tweetText:
Playing Life on Hard Mode

I used to think that not having kids & being childfree was playing life on "easy mode". And it is, in certain ways.

But as I've gotten older, I've also realized that being childfree is also akin to playing life on hard mode, in a few but important ways.

When you have kids, the north star is clear. There's a clear priority for your life. And the structure's also clear. (Or at least, more clear.) For most ppl, everything is done in service of your family, with your kids being first. How much money you need to make. What kind of work you need to do to make that money. How much you need to save. All these kinds of constraints do tie you down, but they also give form & purpose to your life. They keep you grounded & tethered to reality.

Every day, if you have kids, by simply making it through the day, you have contributed to your children's development. You've answered their questions, fed them, and have helped them grow. Every day, even if you're purely moving through the world in a reactive mode, you've done something meaningful w/ your life. (Or at least, moved the needle forward in some small way. At very minimum, you're at least contributing to the future tax base of your country. You are contributing to a collective project, larger than yourself!)

But in the absence of children being the forcing function, childfree ppl need to be disciplined ab how they structure their life. Not for one day, one week, or one year. But for your entire life. Also, you have to make sure you're actually doing something w/ your life. When you're childless, it's easy to squander entire days without contributing anything to anyone.

title: Chinese Brand Supremacy?
tweetText:
Chinese Brand Supremacy?

Maybe it was inevitable, but I've noticed an increasing number of my personal devices switch over to Chinese brands. First was my laptop yrs ago (Lenovo from Dell). Then my scooter (NIU). And now I'm considering an Open (OnePlus from Samsung). For yrs, everything was made in China (eg. your fancy MacBook) but then other companies just slapped their logo over it. But now I think China's finally getting into the international market w/ their own premium Chinese brands. (The other obvious example here is TikTok. But not me! Still on X. "üôÇ")

As of now though, I do still use:
- Microsoft (US) - keyboard
- Logitech (Swiss) - mouse
- Bose (US) - headphones

It's just a bit of cognitive dissonance for me bc for years I've never associated Chinese brands with quality (w/ the exception of Lenovo. And honestly, that's just bc I use ThinkPad, which they'd acquired from IBM). To me, quality always meant American, Japanese, or Korean. Or maybe a European country (for cars, for example). But I think that's changing now. Chinese brands are ascendant! A whole new generation of Americans are going to grow up regularly using TikTok, Shein, and Temu, thinking that Chinese companies are the cream of the crop. (And if American car companies weren't protected by US tariffs, BYD would likely be a huge Tesla competitor, I think.)

Am curious though‚Äî what brands are ppl using nowadays? Do you see a shift towards Chinese ones?

title: Scooter Speeds: European Mode vs American Mode
tweetText:
My scooter has been in "European Mode" which means it was capped at 25 kph (15 mph). (That is apparently the speed restriction by law over there.) Today, a firmware update finally released that allows it to now go 32 kph (20 mph). American mode! There's a huge difference!

Maybe this is confirmation bias, but it honestly feels like a through line to me that everything is so much more regulated in Europe: GDPR, no AC at the Olympics, and scooter max speeds. I'm happy to be proved wrong though!

Question: what is something that Europe is more laissez-faire ab, compared to America? "ü§î"

title: 'Why Men Are 'Rawdogging' Flights' | GQ
tweetText:
It's interesting to me how as a child & younger person, I really enjoyed being active & doing things. But then as an adult, I've noticed that I increasingly enjoy resting more if I have free time. Rather than mindlessly watch YouTube or go out just for the sake of going out, I increasingly prefer staying inside & collecting my thoughts or just letting my mind go blank altogether. Also, when I work I now listen to music less & less as well.

I used to think that quiet time & space was a time to fill with activity. But now my powers of concentration need to be more... conserved & focused? It's almost as if any activity at all depletes me in some way. Even "passive" activities like listening to music.

I can't speak for other men, but I wonder if this is a new trend that's happening. "ü§î"
